Virginia is unique in that it allows the Commonwealth to demand a jury trial and it allows juries to impose the punishment (at least as a recommendation which judges are reluctant to overturn). In a primarily rural community you tend to get a conservative minded (and large sentence leaning) juror. In my jurisdiction 99% of all jury trials happen because the Commonwealth wants one-defendants almost never request one because they are afraid of the jury sentence option (although you see far fewer jury trial demands by prosecutors in large, urban jurisdictions because the jury pool is vastly different).
 
 For cocaine dealers, as an example, we demand jury trials for all cases, and they almost always end up pleading guilty straight up without any plea bargain offer rather than risk a jury sentence. They do so because they know the average sentence statewide from a judge is 12-18 months per cocaine sale charge on a guilty plea (because a judge can suspend time), whereas a jury starts at the statutory minimum five years per charge and can go up to 40 years-and in my experience jurors not only rarely give the minimum but they tend to count by fives (10,15,20,25 years).
